fullDescription:
The Latin Voice of Scandinavian Legend - Denmark's Medieval Historian

Saxo Grammaticus provides the most extensive Latin account of Scandinavian legendary history and mythology. His Gesta Danorum (Deeds of the Danes), completed around 1200 CE, offers a perspective on Norse myths distinct from the Icelandic tradition of Snorri Sturluson. Where Snorri preserved the mythology relatively intact, Saxo thoroughly euhemerized the gods into ancient kings and heroes, transforming sacred narrative into legendary history.

Little is known of Saxo's life beyond what can be inferred from his work. His epithet "Grammaticus" ("the Learned" or "the Lettered") was added posthumously, attesting to his reputation for Latin eloquence. He was likely a clerk in the service of Archbishop Absalon of Lund (1128-1201), the powerful churchman who commissioned the Gesta Danorum. Saxo may have been a canon at the cathedral of Lund or Roskilde, and his sophisticated Latin style suggests education at a major European center, possibly Paris.

Gesta Danorum (c. 1200 CE)

Saxo's monumental work comprises sixteen books covering Danish history from legendary times to 1187. The first nine books contain the mythological and legendary material that makes Saxo invaluable for the study of Scandinavian tradition:

Books I-II: The earliest legendary kings, including the god-kings who ruled in prehistoric times. Here Odin appears as Othinus, a cunning mortal king who achieved divine status through magic and deception. The gods are consistently presented as powerful sorcerers and warriors rather than true deities.

Books III-IV: The story of Amlethus (Hamlet), the legendary Danish prince whose tale Shakespeare would later immortalize. Saxo's version is the earliest complete narrative of the Hamlet legend.

Book V-VIII: Legendary heroes including Ragnar Lodbrok, Starkad the Old, and the Skj√∂ldung dynasty. These books preserve heroic legends otherwise lost or fragmentary.

Book IX: The transition from legend to history, including the conversion of Denmark to Christianity.

Books X-XVI: Historical accounts of Danish kings from Gorm the Old to Canute VI, based on written sources and oral testimony.

Euhemerism and Interpretation

Saxo's treatment of Norse mythology differs fundamentally from Snorri's. Where Snorri framed the gods as Trojan refugees who were later worshipped as deities, Saxo goes further: his gods are entirely human, their divine status the result of deception, magic, and the credulity of primitive Danes.

Othinus (Odin) in Saxo is a cunning sorcerer who traveled to Byzantium, mastered dark arts, and convinced the ignorant that he was a god. When his wife Frigga cuckolded him with a slave, Othinus departed in shame - a detail found nowhere in Icelandic sources. Saxo's Thor (called Thoro) is merely a formidable warrior. Balderus (Baldr) is a Danish king killed in battle by the Swedish hero Hotherus (H√∂√∞r) over the love of the maiden Nanna - transformed from cosmic tragedy to heroic romance.

This euhemeristic approach reflects Saxo's Christian perspective: the pagan gods could not be real, so they must have been mortals whose reputations grew into divinity. Yet this very skepticism preserved details of Norse tradition that more sympathetic treatments might have suppressed or sanitized.

Unique Contributions

Saxo preserves material found nowhere else in Norse literature:

1. The Amlethus (Hamlet) legend in complete form
2. Alternative versions of the Baldr myth with significant variations
3. Extensive Starkad traditions and the hero's tragic fatalism
4. Danish perspectives on shared Scandinavian legends
5. Detailed accounts of sorcery, prophecy, and supernatural beings
6. The only Latin verses translated from Old Norse poetry (now lost)

His account of the Baldr story is particularly significant: in Saxo, Balderus and Hotherus are rival kings, not divine brothers. Balderus is killed in battle after being wounded by a magical sword forged by the forest-dwellers. This "historical" version may preserve an older stratum of the legend than Snorri's cosmic drama.

Literary Style

Saxo wrote in elaborate, rhetorical Latin modeled on classical authors, particularly Valerius Maximus, Justin, and Martianus Capella. His prose is ornate to the point of obscurity, earning him both admiration and criticism. The sixteenth-century Danish printer Christiern Pedersen noted that Saxo's Latin was so difficult that even learned men struggled with it.

This classical veneer sometimes obscures the Scandinavian material beneath, but it also ensured the work's survival and prestige in a Latin-reading medieval world. Saxo's elaborate style was a deliberate choice to elevate Danish history to the level of classical historiography.

Historical Context

Saxo wrote during Denmark's medieval golden age under the Valdemar dynasty. Archbishop Absalon, who conquered R√ºgen from the Wends and founded Copenhagen, wanted a national history that would rival the chronicles of other European kingdoms. The Gesta Danorum served both as national glorification and as a demonstration that Scandinavian culture could compete with Mediterranean sophistication.

Legacy

Saxo's influence extends far beyond Norse studies. The Amlethus narrative became the source for Shakespeare's Hamlet through Fran√ßois de Belleforest's French adaptation. The work was first printed in Paris in 1514 and remained the standard history of Denmark for centuries.

For Norse mythology, Saxo provides an essential counterpoint to the Icelandic sources. His Danish perspective, Christian interpretation, and euhemeristic method illuminate aspects of the tradition that Snorri, with his poetic preservation focus, might have passed over. Together, Snorri and Saxo form the twin pillars of our knowledge of Scandinavian mythology and legend.
